Although the first part featured by Harrison Ford obtained much more box office , this second part also achieved success in spite of the storyline was basically a rehash of the previous film that was it equally of television episodes scripted by Roy Huggins and starred by David Janssen.The Fugitive (1993) contains an atmospheric and moving musical score by James Newton Howard . Likewise , evocative and colorful cinematography by cameraman Michael Chapman . The motion picture was well directed by Andrew Davis , a filmmaker with a reputation for directing intelligent thrillers . He has made good films as ¨Above the law¨, ¨The final terror¨ , ¨Chain reaction¨ , ¨Collateral damage¨ , ¨The Package¨ and Davis went on to direct 1992's top grossing picture, ¨Under siege¨ (1992), for Warner Brothers, a classic action film teaming Steven Seagal with Tommy Lee Jones . Being his greatest hit ¨The fugitive¨ , this film received seven Academy Award nominations including Best Picture and earned Tommy Lee Jones a Best Supporting Actor award. Andrew Davis frequently casts 'Ron Dean', Joseph F. Kosala, Joe Pantoliano and his father 'Nathan Davis' . He often directs in his city : Chicago .

This was a decent action/detective movie with good pacing and good acting all around. My main problem with the movie centers around the holes in the plot: while it's suggested, it's never clearly stated why Helen was murdered; the fudged clinical trials of the drug all being ultimately controlled by one doctor seems rather unlikely; the number of times Kimble goes unrecognized by people who should know him on-sight (even without the beard) goes beyond the realm of unlikely into the realm of ludicrous; Kimble's skill at creating a false pass and faking out people who work at the hospital also seems rather lame. I'm sure I could come up with more if I watched it again.In the end, it was a good enough movie to be enjoyable, but some very basic believability issues marred the overall story. Obviously the 90% or so of users who rated this movie better than I did will disagree with me on this, but I have a hard time understanding why this movie is so highly-rated. It was okay, but I don't feel any pressing need to watch it again at any point.

A respectful Doc who has a great heart and all his people likes him found himself accused be murdering his wife!
Great acting with a lot of thriller; with a whole honor of all sides the police officer who sticks to duty to seeks justice by the law and on the other side a man who's fight for his justice without forgetting his Humanity.

reviews.review_title: Classic Ford/Jones hide n seek story.
reviews.content: Not a new movie, in fact almost 20 years old, but I managed to catch it on the ION network this weekend. Ford and Jones look pretty young.The movie begins in the home at night, the wife is in her night clothes, there is a struggle, she ends up dead and the husband is accused of murder. We very briefly see the trial and a guilty verdict sends him to prison.Harrison Ford is the husband, Dr. Richard Kimble. He maintains his innocence and claims a "one-armed man" was in their home, he struggled with him, was knocked out and doesn't remember much.As he is being transported to prison there is a scuffle in the bus, it veers off the road, and tumbles down the embankment. When a guard says to him "you're a doctor, can you help him" regarding an injured man, Kimble answers "take my cuffs off." The movie might have ended quickly had it not been that the bus rolled onto train tracks, and now a train was about to hit. Kimble manages to get to safety and it took 90 minutes to determine for certainty that he had not died in the wreck but in fact escaped. The hunt was on.The hunt is directed by Tommy Lee Jones as US Marshall Samuel Gerard. And most of the rest of the movie involves the cat 'n mouse game, Gerard trying to track down Kimble. While Kimble's motive was to gather evidence to prove his innocence.Good movie, Ford and Jones are in top form here.SPOILERS: Kimble works his way back to Chicago and the hospital where he had worked. He pieced together clues that led him to the assassin with the prosthetic arm, and eventually back to another doctor who had been falsifying data in an important drug test to gain its approval. Dr Kimble was the target, not his wife, because he could expose the fraud and there was lots of $$Money on the line. All is well that ends well.

This was a case of they don't make them like that anyone. The Fugitive was a serious yet really entertaining thriller that started as a man on the run trying to prove his innocence to a bigger conspiracy that needed to be exposed. It was a film that had a well-executed plot and excellent set-pieces, especially in the first act. Tommy Lee Jones was fantastic as Samuel Gerard who was determined to find Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford.)This was a film that was so iconic that The Simpsons, American Dad. Scrubs. and Bojack Horseman have parodied it in some way.

reviews.review_title: An Innocent Man On The Run
reviews.content: Of all the old TV shows that have become big-screen movies, THE FUGITIVE must be one of the very few that actually works.  A transfer to the big screen of a fine TV series that starred the late David Janssen and ran on ABC-TV from 1963 to 1967, THE FUGITIVE had all the earmarks of a great film, and it does not disappoint.Taking over for Janssen, Harrison Ford stars as Dr. Richard Kimble, a prominent Chicago surgeon who is convicted for the brutal slaying of his wife Helen (Sela Ward)--a crime he did not commit.  While on his way to meet his fate in an Illinois prison, the bus he and other prisoners are riding in suffers an accident, and is literally crushed by a freight train.  Ford manages to make it out of the wreckage and escapes into the woods.  Now, however, he not only has the whole Illinois state police and the Chicago P.D. on his trail, he also has a phalanx of U.S. marshals, led by the tenacious Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones).With all the odds stacked against him, Ford constantly has to change his appearance to avoid detection while at the same time going after the one-armed man who actually killed his wife.  The result is a gripping cat-and-mouse game through the streets of the Windy City, a literal battle of wits between Ford and Jones that made for some of the best movie-making of the Nineties.Superbly directed by Andrew Davis (UNDER SIEGE; CODE OF SILENCE), THE FUGITIVE is not only a brilliant big-screen translation of a fine TV show from the past, it also echoes a theme familiar to Alfred Hitchcock--a man on the run for a crime he never committed.  Ford is the man in that position. Jones won a well-deserved Supporting Actor Oscar for his role as Gerard, but as Jones himself readily admitted, it is Ford's portrayal of Richard Kimble that is at the heart of this great thriller.  Not nearly as violent as a lot of action films have tended to be, THE FUGITIVE is one of the finest in its genre, well worth seeing.

Dr Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) is a renowned doctor and all round nice guy who is wrongly convicted for the murder of his own wife when the police find only evidence on Kimble and no evidence supporting his claim that his wife was killed by a one armed man now sentenced to death he's transported by prison bus to death row when a group of convicts cause the bus to crash everyone escapes and now Kimble is now a fugitive on the run from the police and a bad ass US Marshall Samuel Gerard played by (Tommy Lee Jones) what ensues is a cat and mouse game between a dedicated US Marshall and a highly intelligent Doctor determined to find the man who killed his wife and clear his own name.This movie is an absolute classic and is regarded as one of the best and most memorable performances of both Harrison Fords and Tommy Lee Jones careers and it's easy to see why both are at the top of their game here and both work well together as Co Star's both giving a commanding performance that grabs your attention in different ways you want them both to win but neither of them to lose at the same time.If you haven't already seen this classic Drama/Action movie then do yourself a favour and watch The Fugitive you won't be disappointed with it.

reviews.review_title: Great Taut Suspense. Too much noise.
reviews.content:
For its period this was a very popular film, and I watched it then, and have finished watching it again.It's very good if you like suspense, because there is an almost constant tension. For me, it's just too much.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
I like the whole set up of an accomplished and wealthy doctor becoming a member of society's dregs, all the
while he's innocent. Using his problem-solving acumen, he goes about hunting down the culprits.While not a meandering jigsaw puzzle, it's a taut mystery that feeds enough revelation to keep the mystery lovers
on the back foot and satisfied. While somewhat simplistic, it's fine.My chief complaint is the constant noise end-to-end in the film --- it never stops! By noise I mean music,
vehicles exploding, police vehicles, ambulances, OMG ... it's endless ... but they wouldn't do this unless
enough viewers enjoy constant noise. I do not.ACTING:
The overall acting ranges from OK to good. Jones and Ford obviously consume 99% of the air, but their
skills are quite different. Jones was a good pick for his character because like many actors it's the only
role he fits. Ford has a much wider range of both emotion and capability, though he has maintained
very similar roles throughout his career.A fair amount of the acting felt TV-ish.TEMPO:
Non-stop, please be quiet, you're giving me a headache, paceCINEMATOGRAPHY:
OK if you like looking at people with guns and hospitalsDIRECTING / WRITING:
When many of a director's films include Chuck Norris and Steven Seagal, I'd normally puke. This guy does have
some talent, but I'd give him a "C" in general and here in particular. Both writers were of the same ilk, and their
films have the same flavor --- men with guns ... and lots and lots of noise.Is it a very good film? No.Should you watch this once? Yes, if you like suspense and noise.Rating: 7.0.

reviews.review_title: The Fugitive Should Have Fled With the Script **
reviews.content: After one has seen the outstanding television series, you realize what a disappointment the 1993 film was.The fast pacing of the show wasn't there and Tommy Lee Jones winning the best supporting actor award for his performance as Girard was ridiculous. (The award belonged to Ralph Fiennes for his brilliant portrayal of Nazi killer Amon Goeth in "Schindler's List.")The television show was a guessing game of Dr. Richard Kimball's whereabouts. To think, in the movie, the good doctor was hiding out in the hospital all along. This is ludicrous. Don't you think that the police would have looked into this right away?

reviews.review_title: How to make a good thriller... solid Ford, great Tommy lee jones
reviews.content: Andrew Davis' fugitive is one of the most suspenseful and well acted thrillers from the 90s. I respect this film because it featured a couple actors (ford and Jones) that are not my favorites but give two of their best performances here. However highlight was still Joe Pantoliano for me, he was great in his role as a deputy marshal. The story is a bout wrongfully framed doctor who is on the run from the US marshalls. It is a well written script, and is suspenseful and interesting at all times. This film was very entertaining to watch. It drags you along with it, it was a rare time where i cared for Ford's character, i think Davis got it right with this one, simply a very good thriller 9/10

I've known about The Fugitive since the 90s but for some reason never saw the movie. I'm glad I finally checked it out. It was better than I expected. Instead of being "just a minor Harrison Ford movie" it was actually an above average thriller.The two lead stars, Ford and Tommy Lee Jones raise the quality level, but I think also the script and directing is tight. The plot stays interesting at all points, with new twists and turns, and the balance of action and slower scenes is perfect. And the action scenes are well shot, and the overall cinematography is beautiful with aerial views and such.I recommend this movie if you like thrillers with some action, adventure, and an interesting plot.

reviews.review_title: Ford runs this explosive facelift of the old TV series.
reviews.content: Not so many TV-to-film transfers can live up to greatness, but THE FUGITIVE can prove that enhancing an original plotline with a right edge can turn into a super movie. The added suspense lives up to calling this just another mega-thriller that differs the original black-and-white series. Both Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are fully demanding in giving this the raw energy a simple cat-and-mouse story needs. For interesting terminology, the leading characters are on opposite sides of their personalities, with "good" convict Kimble evading the so-called "villainous" U.S. Marshal who is out to capture him. Ford uses the old INDIANA JONES trick in a couple of the riskiest stunts performed on film, but he keeps the action moving. One drawback is that you're now beginning to notice his recent characters a bit more worrisome than heroic, but Ford gets the job done as usual. Much of THE FUGITIVE displays continuous action and suspense until the rousing climax. Look for a hospital nurse that appears in the form of Julianne Moore. This will most likely end up as one of the Top 10 action thrillers of the decade before the 90s is through.

It isn't often when a movie based on a very good & creative old television show surpasses the original but in this case it does, & by a distance. "The Fugitive" is undoubtedly one of the best movies of the 90's & Harrison Ford comes up trumps again. He plays Dr. Richard Kimble was is sentenced to death for murdering his wife, a crime he did not commit. He escapes from custody whilst being transported to the penitentiary where his sentence will be carried out. Right from the start his escape itself from the bus taking him is brilliantly done, very exciting to watch, & things hardly let up for a moment throughout this movie. Tommy Lee Jones plays the leader of the law enforcement officers trying to recapture him & what follows is a very exciting battle of wits between two very intelligent men. The action is superlative as the doctor sets about trying to prove his innocence whilst at the same evading the law. If you haven't seen it & get the chance to watch it, DON'T MISS IT!

reviews.review_title: an excellent thriller and enjoyable action/drama with entertaining performances by Ford and Jones
reviews.content: This is a movie that loses a touch of its flair after the first watch, as a lot of it rides of a sense of mystery and whodunit. Still, even after, it remains an enjoyable thriller with some great action scenes and dialogue. As a big Tommy Lee Jones fan, I'd have to say he stole most of my attention, but there were so many great lines and scenes that only Harrison Ford could have pulled off the way he did. Some of the more dramatic elements were also filmed cleverly, and how the movie begins, right off the bat, is also to be admired.

I wasn't alive to see The Fugitive t.v. program so I can't use it as a reference for The Fugitive the movie. As I've heard from my parents it was a long running series with Dr. Richard Kimble perpetually on the run. Well, in that case, the movie was on point.I thoroughly enjoyed this who dunnit movie. As good as Harrison Ford was as Dr. Richard Kimble, Tommy Lee Jones was better as the lead officer hunting down Dr. Kimble. In fact, I would say that TLJ put his name on the map with his performance. Sure, he was good in Under Siege, but he took it up a notch in The Fugitive.The Fugitive was a terrific story with terrific acting, an all around blast.

reviews.review_title: Starts off with a bang, and then keeps running!
reviews.content: The Fugitive is smart, it is action packed and it gives you characters that you care about.  Harrison Ford invests everything he's got in the role of Richard Kimble.  You want to see him catch the One Armed Man and see his name cleared of murder.  Tommy Lee Jones brings humor and determination to the role of Sam Gerard.  The film starts off with a spectacular train crash, and then takes you on a trip that spans from damns to skyscrapers.  Suspence and action edited masterfully together at the hands of Andrew Davis, mixed in with characters made real by Ford and Jones make The Fugitive one of the best, and smartest action films around.

reviews.review_title: "Run, run, run, run, run, run, run, run,You better run all day,And run all night."
reviews.content: Despite being aware of the film since seeing "Behind the stunt" features on Sky Movies in the late 90's/early 2000's,I somehow have not got round to viewing this title. Signing up recently to Dan Murrell's Patreon and seeing this in the Movie Club section, I got ready to run like hell.View on the film:Only having one chance to do the train crash which frees Kimble, (the thrilling CGI-free stunt was done with the train hitting the prison van at 42 MPH) director Andrew Davis & Scrooged (1988-also reviewed) cinematographer Michael Chapman successfully capture the crash, and ignite a break-neck Thriller atmosphere from crisp wide-shots of the tense Action set-pieces.Backed by a spidery electronic score from James Newton Howard, Davis (who impressively improvised the St. Patrick's Day parade sequence) binds the stunt sequences with glossy hand-held shots winding down every sewer and staircase where Gerard is closing in on Kimble.Joined by a stunning support cast of Joe Pantoliano,Julianne Moore and Richard Riehle, TLJ reunites with Andrew Davis after Under Siege (1992), and gives an excellent performance as Gerard, thanks to TLJ pairing his distinctive no-nonsense gruffness, with an enticing curiosity, as Gerard uncovers more about the case.Doubting if he can trust anyone, Harrison Ford gives a great performance as Kimble, who is given a real urgency by Ford to stay one step ahead of Gerard, along with retaining Kimble's clinical eye from his medical background, in carefully gathering up clues to who the one-armed man is.Whilst revealed later that large amounts of the dialogue was improvised, the screenplay by Jeb Stuart and future Pitch Black director David Twohy sets up proceedings in a compact opening 20 minutes, a tone which the writers continue with in tightly coiled man on the run Thriller sequences where Kimble is on the edge gathering evidence, as Gerard closes in on catching the fugitive.

I have always loved this movie because of its performances and classic story. The action scenes are just as timeless. From the jump off a bus before the train crashes to the plunge from the sewer drain to the lake plus the red lights flickering back and forth while Richard Kimble attacks the one armed man in a subway through its conclusion where Richard discovers that more than one man is in on the murder of his wife, there's plenty to see. This includes the speech Deputy Gerard gives while Richard is running through the forest and the flashbacks of his wife's death. There are many other exciting moments.

When I was growing up, a movie was something big and wonderful and original.  Now you can go to the movies and see a television show. Tommy Lee Jones won an Oscar on his name only; all the other nominees that year were more deserving.  Harrison Ford should have better taste than doing this retread.

So watched this movie again on blu ray I forgot how annoying Tommy Lee Jones is in it he didn't need his team as he knows literally everything and treats his team like sh!te the film was okay those but I real say something at the start of the movie the wife gets hit by a heavy object and has a hammeroage but still able to phone the police I don't know she still looked okay to me but I digress

Dr. Richard Kimble never saw it coming. Coming home after an honest day's work he's met by a tragedy that most people think only happens to other people. Arrested, he breaks free and is now on the run. Harrison Ford plays the beleaguered and confused medic as he flees from the law while seeking and taking justice by his own hands. Tommy Lee Jones is the Marshall who's hell bent on catching Kimble whose guilt most are in no doubt about. The plot may not be the most substantial and having grown men running after each other leads to inevitable tediousness but the fast pace of the action takes you along Kimble's run. A huge success in the box office upon release, "The Fugitive" is one fine thriller you wouldn't mind enjoying your popcorn and soda to.

reviews.review_title: My Favorite Movie of All Time
reviews.content: Right from the get go The Fugitive is a perfectly paced exercise in tension with fantastic characters. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are both giving great performances. I am stickler with my 10 ratings, and I rarely hand that out. I have yet to find a film I can remember being this exciting. The end could seem to drag a little long, and you do have to suspend your disbelief somewhat, but I just don't care. A perfect movie.

I must have seen this a long time ago, but my recollection of it was of a generic, almost made-for-TV thriller with only the bit with Harrison Ford jumping off the dam being memorable. For me it kind of got lumped in with that late 80s, early 90s Presumed Innocent/Fatal Attraction-era of 'grown-up' thrillers, that I guess eventually got replaced by all those John Grisham courtroom dramas later on.But I've just rewatched it again, and this time round found it to be an extremely well-made rollercoaster of entertainment, with a star-making performance by Tommy Lee Jones. There's a few TV detective-type moments and some cliches in the writing, but it's all done with such verve and force that you are carried along and gripped to the end. Watching it really brought home to me what a rarity a film like this would be today, in the sea of incompetence and identity politics we're all forced to swim. Just a simple, streamlined, fat-free story, built by professionals with the singleminded goal of rewarding the audience's attention with some fun. They just don't make 'em like that anymore.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of its genre
reviews.content:
POSITIVES:1) Tommy Lee Jones is perfect as Samuel Gerrard: so much dry and deadpan humour combined with stone cold seriousness and dedication to his job
2) The two central plot strands of the murder mystery and the cat and mouse game work very well together. This is especially so because of the differing motivations of the two leads. Ford's character is desperate to solve the murder mystery and tries to avoid the cat and mouse game. Meanwhile Jones' character is desperate to win the cat and mouse game and when confronted with the murder mystery proclaims "I don't care!"
3) The action / chase set pieces are fantastic. Especially the dam chase and the St Patrick's Day chase
4) I love the way in which the film shows us, through actions rather than words, that Richard Kimble is a good man. This is done through how he saves the black prison officer's life twice and then saves the little boy's life in the hospitalNEGATIVES:1) In the third act, it is mentioned that it has been a year since The Fugitive escaped at the start of the film. This seems unrealistic to me. Also, I think the film would seem more compact and engaging if all the events took place over a few days
2) While the Tommy Lee Jones scenes are perfect, some of the Harrison Ford scenes drag on a bit. I do think that the runtime could have 20 minutes or so taken off it from these scenes
3) The film definitely asks you to suspend your disbelief a lot; especially with how Ford's character has no military / espionage experience and yet is able to simultaneously evade law enforcement and conduct a murder investigation

A timeless classic, cat and mouse chase for the fugitive Dr. Richard Kimble. Innocence to be proven, this man pulls out all the stops to get to the bottom of his wife's murder, whilst being hunted by the F.B.I.A great film for both Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones.

Dr. Richard Kimble is accused of murdering his wife even though he witnessed a one armed man committing the crime. On his way to death row there is an accident that allows Kimble to escape. The hunt is on. Kimble goes on the hunt to find out who killed his wife and why, and U.S. Marshal Sam Gerard goes on the hunt for Kimble to bring him in. All the events leading up to the great climax make for an amazing cat and mouse thriller.Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones are great in this movie. No matter which one is on the screen you get the same vibe. Their characters both don't want to stop. They want to find who they're looking for, and they're not going to slow down until they do. To me, this is one of Harrison Ford's better roles. To me his films have been dwindling in quality lately. The scenes involving the U.S. Marshals provide some good comic relief that makes the mood of the film more lighthearted until the action picks up again.Andrew Davis does a really good job compacting four years of material from the TV show into a 2 hr. and 10 minute movie. He even gives the film a twist ending that you're not really expecting. What I really like about The Fugitive is that it's a non-stop action film, but it's not a popcorn flick. This is a real serious movie. The characters and dialogue are realistic, and they make use of several different emotions throughout the film. This is a great movie that if you haven't seen it, you should definitely rent or buy it. You won't regret it.8/10

"I would rather read a poorly structured story that has fresh ideas than a tightly structured one with clichés." – Douglas Wood"Television is like the American toaster, you push the button and the same thing pops up every time." – Alfred HitchcockAlfred Hitchcock perfected the "man on the run" genre with such films as "Saboteur", "Foreign Correspondent", "The 39 Steps" and "North By Northwest", all films in which falsely accused men try to evade capture whilst simultaneously trying to prove their innocence. It doesn't matter if our heroes are guilty or why they're being chased, all that matters is that the possibility of capture keeps the audience in constant state of excitement. You might say the entire genre is a MacGuffin: an excuse to spin action.The "man on the run" genre remained dormant for several years before the success of "The Fugitive" gave birth to another round of copycats ("Chain Reaction", "US Marshals", "Eraser", "Enemy of the State", "Minority Report", "The Incredible Hulk", "Quantum of Solace" etc), all released afterwards and each slavishly copying Hitchcock's formula. Where "The Fugitive" differs from these films, though, is in its casting of Tommy Lee Jones. Jones plays a loud-mouthed law-man tasked with hunting Richard Kimble, a doctor falsely accused of murdering his wife. But while most of these "man on the run" films generate their thrills by having the audience side with the "running man" (in this case Harrison Ford), "The Fugitive" is exciting because the audience sides with both hunter and hunted, both Ford and Jones intelligent and resourceful "good guys" who are equally fun to watch.Incidentally, Steven Spielberg's "Minority Report" steals heavily from "The Fugitive". Both films begin with "flashbacks" of a murder, shot in dreamy fragments. Both films feature a sequence in which the hunter and hunted eye one another through bullet proof glass (a cliché of the genre: see everything from "Eraser" to "Salt"). Both films feature a scene in which a commuter on a train sees the fugitive's face on a newspapers whilst sitting directly opposite him. Both films feature the villain being unmasked in front of an audience of partying sophisticates. Both films feature a bad guy who is also a paternal friend and corporate head who frames the hero for the benefit of the "company"....etc etc. But there's tons of other reappropriated scenes as well, like our running man hiding in crowds while their pursuers look down from above, our heroes hiding in dingy apartment blocks while police look for other people, our heroes changing their eyes or cutting their beards to break back into their work places and instead of Harrison Ford jumping off a reservoir we have Tom Cruise jumping off skyscraper cars.But then Spielberg has always been a cliché parasite. "Minority Report" doesn't only stop at "The Fugitive", it lifts scenes from "Se7en" ("Will I kill him? Won't I kill him?"), "A Clockwork Orange", "LA Confidential" (the chief of police is the bad guy, whilst the guy we're supposed to hate, Colin Farrell, is really a hero) and "Blade Runner" (creator of pre-crime kissing Tom Cruise).But it's the "villain clichés" that have become most pervasive. All these films, from "The Fugitive" to "Minority Report" to "Chain Reaction" to "District 9" to "LA Confidential" to "Monster's Inc", feature the "shocking" revelation that the "bad guy" is really an affable corporate head who covers up a crime for the benefit of the company. In "The Fugitive" the villain tries to pass a new pharmaceutical drug, in "Minority" the villain tries to pass a pre-crime law, in "Monster's Inc" the villain tries to pass a new energy plan. Pharmaceuticals, law enforcement, the energy commission...the modern villain is always a tuxedo wearing corporate lackey, all these films incorrect in individualising and personalising processes that are social, collective and systemic, an approach which implies that it is just a question of personal morality rather than social structures. Incidentally, Tommy Lee Jones would continually revisit the archetypal character he created in "The Fugitive". More often than not, Jones plays an authoritative hunter, capable of reinstating order ("US Marshals", "No Country For Old Men", "Electric Mist", "The Hunted", "Men In Black", "Volcano", "Small Soldiers", "In The Valley of Ellah" etc).7.9/10 - Worth two viewings.

This is a fine vehicle for Harrison Ford made even more agreeable by a clever, somewhat tongue in cheek performance by Tommy Lee Jones as a US Marshall out to have a good time getting the bad guy, even though the bad guy might not be so bad, and even though that's irrelevant, but hey, don't think so much and get me some coffee and a chocolate donut with those sprinkles on top, ya hear?This is also a Hollywood producer's orgasmic dream with a chase scene beginning in the first reel and lasting throughout. It is based on the 60s TV show of the same name, but gets its premise from a true crime story, that of Ohioan Dr. Sam Shepherd who actually went to jail for murdering his wife in the 50s. He too claimed to have fought off the real killer, but the forensic evidence and his personality were against him. Here we have Harrison Ford as the good doctor, and it doesn't take a Hollywood genius to tell you that the most popular leading man of the late twentieth century ain't about to play the kind of guy who murders his loving wife.Ford does a stand-up, competent job, saving lives and patting kids on the head as he plunges through sewers and off the top of a towering waterfall, steals an ambulance, survives a bullet wound and a bus wreck, etc. His fans will be pleased, but Tommy Lee Jones steals the show (and got a Best Supporting Oscar for his trouble) as a clever, wise-cracking good ole boy who has a lot of fun leading the posse. I wonder if he or director Andrew Davis invented the spin because without it, this wouldn't be half so good.

reviews.review_title: Harrison Ford searches for one armed man
reviews.content: Big screen version of the popular 60s tv show basically the same but updated a bit for the times This 1993 classic has Harrison Ford as the falsely accused Dr Kimble and Tommy Lee Jones as the relentless us attorney. Harrison Ford does an outstanding job as does Tommy Lee Jones who was nominated for an oscar.. Sela Ward turns in a brief role as the slain doctor's wife and is very sexy. The movie is one long roller coaster from start to finish with virtually no let up..you will definitely be watching at the edge of your seat...spawned sequels with Tommy Lee Jones character and a semi sequel with Double jeopardy Was second highest grossing movie in 93 a must see especially for action fans, Harrison Ford Fans..and anyone else On a scale of one to ten ... a 9

reviews.review_title: Another solid Harrison Ford thriller. Part chase, part detective, but suspenseful from the start till the end.
reviews.content: The good: Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford.More good: this is simply another solidly made suspenseful thriller. It's not brilliant or very original, but it pushes the right buttons, it has got glorious music, it has got a conniving bad guy, it has got some great chases.Any bad? Well, with all of these Hollywood blockbusters there are several stupid plot turns that arent credible whatsoever, but who cares, because I got entertained from beginning to end.

reviews.review_title: Much better then the TV series that its based on
reviews.content: ***MAJOR SPOILERS*** On his way to death row at the Stateville Correctional Center outside of Joliet Ill fate, after screwing him at every turn, intervened in convicted murderer Dr. Richard Kimble's, Harrison Ford, favor.A blotched escape attempt from the prison bus engineered by desperate and deranged death row inmate Edward "Big BoBo" Copeland, Eddie "Bo" Smith Jr, gave Kimble a new lease on life. Making his way back north to Chicago Kimble is now determined to find the person who murdered his wife Helen, Sela Ward, who he was falsely convicted of murdering. With the local police state troopers and even the US Marshall Service hot on his tail Kimble goes straight into the dragons teeth not to escape the law but enforce it! In him finding the killer whom the local,Chicago PD, authorities had completely overlooked in his wife's murder: The notorious one, or prosthetic, arm man who was secretly a paid hit-man for a major US pharmaceutical company!Disregarding those chasing after him that includes US Marshall Samuel Gerard, Tommy Lee Jones, Kimble finds out the real shocking reason that his wife was brutally murdered and it had to do with a case of mistaken identity. It was him, Richard Kimble, not Helen who was the killers actual target!Mile a minute action thriller with Dr. Kimble, with a bum knee no less, running the length of the Chicago Marathon in his pursuit of justice where at the same time justice, in the Chicago PD FBI and US Marshals, trying to both capture and have him executed for a crime that he didn't commit! Having uncovered the truth about this drug Provasic causing serious liver damage to those who use it Kimble didn't at first realize what he was getting into by trying to bring that major fact about the drug out to the American people. ***SPOILERS*** With literally billions of dollars at stake the company that produced Provasic put a hit out on Kimble in order to shut him up an thus have the drug, with approval by the Food and Drug Administration, made available to the public. As Kimble slowly started to uncover the truth to who were both behind his wife's murder and those who hired him to do it his only hope now is, by using himself as bait, to draw them out into the open. Powerhouse final with Kimble having it out with both his wife's killer, on a Chicago El-Train, and the person who hired him, at a major Chicago Medical Convention Center, with the Chicago PD and US Marshall Gerard unwittingly coming to his rescue. Something that was the last thing on their minds in trying to either shoot or apprehend, as a dangerous fugitive, Dr. Richard Kimble during the entire movie!

reviews.review_title: Let the cat & mouse chase begin..
reviews.content: One of the best movies of the 90's. Ford & Jones shine, and the movie has enough twists and turns to think you're in a maze. Never dulls or bores for one moment. Cops chasing an innocent man, man trying to lead cops to the guilty man, U.S. Marshal obsessed with finding the man. The cat & mouse chase is on. Jones gives his Oscar-worthy & winning performance his all, and along with Ford, they make one of the best on-screen teams of the decade. If you have not seen this movie, rent and you will not be sorry. One of the best parts is when Harrison saves a 12-year old boy's life while posing as a janitor at a hospital.

reviews.review_title: This film is both exciting and very tense.
reviews.content: Based on the great original t.v. series from the sixities, "The Fugitive", directed by Andrew Davis ("Under Siege") is just as entertaining as the tv series itself.   It's about Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), who is convicted for the murder of his wife, Helen (Sela Ward) in Chicago.  The local detectives think Kimble did it for the money while Kimble knows that he was framed by a man with artificial limb.   He gets the chance to prove his innocence by escaping a frightening train-bus wreck.   Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones, who won a Best Supporting Oscar) and his small band of U.S. Marshals arrive at the scene and follow the clues that Kimble leaves for them.  It doesn't take too long for Gerard and Kimble to meet face-to-face, they meet in a sewer.    Kimble, who's holding Gerard's gun, says to Gerard in a scared tone, " I didn't kill my wife." Gerard quickly replies, " I don't care." That leads to one of the best scenes in the movie where Kimble jumps off the edge of a dam right into a river. That's pure filmmaking and stunts like this are common in a Davis film.   I liked Gerard's description of Kimble's escape to Cosmo Renfro (Joe Pantliano), his main deputy "He did a 'Peter Pan' right off the top of this dam.  Right here."   The second half of the film is mostly a patient cat-and-mouse chase.  It isn't fast-paced as the first and the ending is well-made.  What makes "The Fugitive" work so well is I didn't only root for Kimble, but I rooted (and laughed) for Gerard as well.  Besides Davis's smart direction and handling of the film's pace, the story by David S. Twohy is masterfully written and is near perfection.     Harrison Ford gives another unforgettable performance as Kimble, but Jones is the stand out here as Gerard.  The supporting cast is great, too and "The Fugitive" is a classic film that shouldn't go unseen.

reviews.review_title: Exciting game of cat and mouse with an underwhelming final act
reviews.content: Thoroughly entertaining non-stop drama featuring Harrison Ford at his sombre best. A bit corny round the edges but stands out among the vast array of nineties action movies. Ending is scrappy and prolonged, certainly didn't leave me as surprised or satisfied as it might have done.

I always like a good crime action thriller, and this is another fantastic one based on a TV series. Basically well respected surgeon Dr. Richard Kimble (Golden Globe nominated Harrison Ford) found his wife Helen (Sela Ward) ferociously murdered at home, and the police mistakenly found him and he was accused of murder. He was then tried, convicted and sentenced to death, however, he manages to escape when the prisoner transport bus crashes. Kimble is now on the run, both escaping the cops, led by Marshal Samuel Gerard (Oscar and Golden Globe winning, and BAFTA nominated Tommy Lee Jones), and trying to find the guilty man and prove his innocence. Also starring Julianne Moore as Dr. Anne Eastman, Joe Pantoliano as Deputy Marshal Cosmo Renfro, Andreas Katsulas as Frederick Sykes, The Living Daylights' Jeroen Krabbé as Dr. Charles Nichols, Daniel Roebuck as Deputy Marshal Robert Biggs, L. Scott Caldwell as Deputy Marshal Poole, Tom Wood as Deputy Marshal Noah Newman, Ron Dean as Detective Kelly and Joseph F. Kosala as Detective Rosetti. The action and some stunt sequences are exhilarating, Jones deserved the Oscar, and this film has very witty pace. Jones returned in a sequel, U.S. Marshals in 1998, which obviously cannot come close to the great action and thrills of this. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Cinematography, Best Sound Effects Editing, Best Film Editing, Best Music for James Newton Howard, Best Sound and Best Picture, it won the BAFTA for Best Sound, and it was nominated for Best Editing and Best Special Effects, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Director for Andrew Davis. Harrison Ford was number 5 on The 100 Greatest Movie Stars, and the film was number 33 on 100 Years, 100 Thrills. Very good!
This film is really good, a film about an innocent man being wrongly accused and he's trying to prove he's innocence while on the run from the law. Great cast and a great story to fit.

Revisiting The Fugitive was 131 minutes well spent.My favorite line. Tomy Lee Jones: "I need a rest". This is a rollercoaster of a film viewing experience. The action never ceases, and the plot and characters are at least 51% of the time believable. I'm wondering how Harrison Ford survives that long waterfall jump, and in soaked clothing manages to avoid dieing of hypothermia wrapped up in nothing but a bed of leaves in the dead of winter. But then he is a doctor. And they can do things like that because they know everything.

reviews.review_title: Thinking man's actioner; one of the best big-screen tv adaptations!
reviews.content: THE FUGITIVE (1993) **** Harrison Ford, Tommy Lee Jones, Joe Pontaliano, Sela Ward, Jeroen Krabbe, Andreas Katsulas, Julianne Moore.  The ultimate manhunt chase film.  Top-notch adaptation of popular sixties' tv series with David Janssen, has Ford as wrongly accused murderer Dr. Richard Kimble on the lam to catch the one-armed man who brutally killed his wife.  Jones (in his brilliant scene stealing Best Supporting Actor Oscar winning performance) is Federal Agent Gerard, the man obsessed with nabbing his man and only one step behind in his dogged pursuit.  Excellently staged stunts and surprisingly affective acting from both men out for justice. Emphatically directed by Andrew Davis featuring a train collision, one of the best action sequences ever filmed.
One of the best thrillers I've ever seen. Tension in every scene. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Great! Better than any Jim Carrey movie or 'Silence of the Lambs.'
reviews.content: "I don't care!" In "The Fugitive," when, after Dr. Richard Kimble (played by Harrison Ford) insists to the Federal Marshall (played by Tommy Lee Jones) chasing him -- over a levelled-at-him gun, no less -- that "I didn't kill my wife!" he gets a response along the lines of: "Good for you! Tell it to the judge! Sadly, that's not my job." The look on Harrison Ford's face is priceless -- this is what's been consuming his life, after all, and it's not the response he's expecting -- and the whole movie taking a double-antagonist, "chase him!" "now, run away!" position where you're rooting for both the two main characters -- they each have their reasons -- is very curious and a weird place to put the audience in. One of the best blockbuster movies of the '90s, and sadly neglected, though it's a lotta fun (great train wreck) and periodically very funny (never mind it's an apt pairing, for once, of two giants of the screen against each other -- isn't this what we go to star-driven movies *for* ... ?).

This was a great cat and mouse action film that kept me on my toes as a wrongly convicted man desperately searched for the true killer of his wife while being on the run. Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones were impressive in this movie honestly.

'The Fugitive' is quite a bit more faithful to its source material than many other feature films inspired by old television series, at least in an elemental sense. Most of the key reference points are there; innocent Dr. Richard Kimble, his wife's murder, the dogged pursuit by police Lt. Gerard, and of course the one-armed man. We hardly expect the main actors to impersonate their antecedents and they don't, though the thought of Harrison Ford mimicking David Janssen is an amusing one. But where the film really deviates from the TV show is in Tommy Lee Jones' portrayal of the Gerard character. Barry Morse's staid police lieutenant may have had just a touch of deviousness to him, but it's nothing compared to Jones' flamboyant, in-your-face, control-freakish turn as the U.S. marshal on Kimble's trail. Jones' Gerard is every bit as much a lead character as Ford's quieter, determined Kimble. There are new twists (and a new sub-plot concerning pharmaceutical subterfuge) added to the familiar plot of Dr. Kimble on the run, trying to locate evidence that the one-armed man killed his wife and thus prove his innocence. Kimble is certainly nothing if not resourceful and not surprisingly, a certain suspension of disbelief is required by the audience to accept his ability to get out of scrapes and avoid the police throughout the film. In fact, there are primarily two sources of great enjoyment in 'The Fugitive,' one being Jones' over-the-top performance and the other Kimble's ingenuity at tracking down the murderer even while he himself is being pursued. Another actor deserves mention: Jeroen Krabbe, who plays a doctor friend of Kimble's who ultimately turns out to be one of the baddies. With his cultured accent and sophisticated manner, Krabbe exudes a kind of upper-crust menace very effectively, so that when his character's true nature is revealed, there is a real sense of justice prevailing in his getting his comeuppance. There is a certain infuriating quality about Gerard, for all his wiseass remarks and endearing devil-may-care attitude towards protocol, in that he seemingly never stops to consider whether Kimble just might be innocent, at least not until very late in the film. It stands in contrast to some of Kimble's old friends at the hospital he visits, who are just as unswervingly convinced that he isn't guilty without any physical evidence or proof to back up this belief. Kimble inhabits a no-man's land in the middle, slipping in and out of each alternate universe, one where he's damned for all time and the other where he's a great guy, and don't be silly, of course he didn't kill his wife. It's that tension that propels 'The Fugitive' along but also makes the ending not entirely satisfactory. You want to hit Lt. Gerard on the head when he finally realizes the truth and tell him, "Of course he didn't kill his wife, you fool!"

Harrison Ford is Richard Kimble a doctor who found his wife dead and is unjustly tried and condemned to death but the train that he is being carried in crashed and that US Marshal Sam Gerard played by Tommy Lee Jones is sent to take over there.And how that he and the rest of the Marshals try to get Kimble but that Gerard has now doubts about his guilt. Kimble must disguise himself and goes on the run to clear his name and begins his own investigation there.Really the late David Janssen the original would had been proud had he lived.

A perfect movie. The Fugitive renewed my waning faith in movies. I was on the edge of my seat for the entire film and at the end, I couldn't believe how good it had been. For me, this is Harrison Ford's best film. His performance as Kimble is done excellently. He never overplays and has just the right amount of quietness and anxiousness throughout. Tommy Lee Jones is superb in the brash and grimly amusing Gerard.The Fugitive is also something of a movie to learn some aspects of filmaking by, in the way the story is revealed. The courtroom session takes place between the two starts of opening credits, showing the swift and bewildering sentencing of Kimble. And there is the action : the train wreck is the best crash scene I have ever seen.I'd like to believe if Schindler's List wasn't up the same year that The Fugitive would have walked away with all the Oscars. This movie is smart, brilliantly directed and superbly acted. One of the best movies ever made and my absolute favorite.

reviews.review_title: Snappy, Up-Tempo Action with a Decidedly '90s Aesthetic
reviews.content: Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones race around in circles for this memorable early '90s cat-and-mouse blockbuster, skillfully adapting and modernizing a four-season television series from thirty years prior. The Fugitive doesn't fool around, racing through dozens of heavy plot points in the first hour without feeling overwhelming or hyperactive. It's a succinct, condensed version of a once-sprawling serial, one which trims away the obligatory TV padding without skipping any good bits.While it's trucking through those establishing shots, the story is a whiplash stunner; in the blink of an eye, we see our protagonist as a respected physician, grieving husband, bewildered murder suspect, sentenced convict, opportunistic escapee and outdoor survivalist, with one particularly well-executed train derailment thrown in to really kick off all the turmoil. Almost by necessity, the second act slows down to focus on the chase, balancing Ford's attempts to lay low with Jones's top-of-the-food-chain detective work. That performs well, too, a firm gear-shift from the opening salvo's manic mayhem (one that's certainly assisted by its two phenomenal cornerstone stars), though it does lose its way as all the different points converge and the moment of resolution draws near. By contrast, the ending falls more on the bland, derivative side; careful suspense cast aside in favor of a big chair-tossing, pipe-swinging, rock'em'sock'em finale. These scenes are inoffensive, but a decided step down from what we'd seen and felt just prior. Put it this way: I still vividly recalled the bus crash and dam jump, decades after I last saw them. I'd forgotten all about the climactic rooftop fist fight.While the gettin's good, it's real good. A fairly simple premise with plenty of intrigue and gray morality, a tight script, more than one all-decade action set, a super-sized portion of Tommy Lee Jones intensity and lots and lots of chances for grim Harrison Ford to glance worriedly over his shoulder. Maybe not perfect, but it still holds up.

I've seen "The Fugitive" dozens of times over the years, and it's one of the most enduring and intelligent thrillers ever made. Like any thriller by director William Friedkin, it's basically one long chase that never pauses or lets you take a breather; it's that exhausting an experience to watch "The Fugitive." And it has the performances to boot. Based on the television series, Harrison Ford is Dr. Richard Kimble, a respected Chicago surgeon who is wrongfully accused of brutally murdering his wife (Sela Ward). Sentenced to die by lethal injection by the courts, fate and an attempted jail break (culminating in one of the most exciting action sequences in the film) spring Richard free, and place him on the run for his life as he searches for the real killer. The killer in this case, a one-armed man, is the obsession of the good doctor as he dawns disguises and tries to stay one step ahead of dogged F.B.I. marshal Sam Gerard (Best Supporting Actor Oscar-winner Tommy Lee Jones) and his team of law enforcement officers. And the chase is on. As the picture roles, we're in the action with two men who are both chasing after radically different goals; it's the hunter and the hunted. We're with Ford's desperate doctor as he searches vigorously for a fiendish murderer, and we're with Jones' agent as he tracks Kimble's trail. Andrew Davis ("Under Siege") directs the film's frequent chase sequences with intense focus that is reminiscent of what we've become used to in Friedkin's action films. It's really exciting stuff here.10/10

Imagine a time, if you will, when fugitive movies were not released ten times a year, a time when Tommy Lee Jones actually appeared in fugitive movies simply because he liked the script and not because he was revisiting the role that made him famous again, a time when the fugitive movies were about much more than simply a homicidal maniac being chased by a man who has a connection to him. You will understand this film a lot more.It relies so much on characters and a witty script as compared to explosions and fight scenes. But of course that's not to say it doesn't have any pyrotechnics or chase scenes or battles - the action scenes will satisfy even the biggest of action buffs. It just makes a lot more sense when they're there for a purpose.Harrison Ford plays Dr. Ryan Kimble. Kimble comes home from work one night after an emergency procedure at the hospital to find his wife brutally beaten to death by a one-armed man. The one-armed man escapes from the scene of the crime and all evidence points to Ryan as the assaultant and killer.After sentenced to death, Ryan is pushed into the back of a convict bus transporting convicted fellons to jail. But one of the criminals tries to escape and the bus ends up swerving off the road and flipping down a steep ravine, coming to rest upon a railroad track. Ryan escapes before the train rips through the bus, resulting in a great scene where Ryan is running in front of the derailed train, chained at his feet and arms. It's the classic Indiana Jones bolder scene redux.Ryan eventually disappears into the woods and U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones) arrives at the scene of the crash a short time later. He is the ultimate seeker; he is barely ever wrong about anything, and when he is he doesn't like to admit it. Jones presents his character with such a sense of self-confidence and oozing calmness that his Oscar was well-deserved.Ryan keeps on running throughout the film, only stopping to gather evidence of his killer and then moving on. He goes through some interesting scenarios and starts to stumble upon a conspiracy, but no one will hear his story - the only living person who might care is the same man who says he doesn't care: Sam Gerard.If I am correct in my observations, Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones only appear in about two scenes together - the rest of the film they are apart from each other. As Jones pursues Ford, it seems as though he starts to make a connection with his prey - as though he may be the only one understanding what Ford is doing and why. It creates a sense of greater suspense for the audience. This is not a run-of-the-mill chase picture we are exploited to on so many occasions. We care for both characters in equal regards, and when they finally do come face-to-face it results in a kind of unexpected payoff; at last we get to see the two together in the same shot and it's strangeThe movie is directed by Andrew Davis, who directed "Collateral Damage" and "Holes." He has a solid sense of direction even if the material itself doesn't always hold together. Given a terrific script like "The Fugitive," Davis creates a type of cement cornerstone that is the base of the film. The script and direction compliment themselves often, something that can't be said in most cases.Tommy Lee Jones recently appeared in "The Hunted," a film about a madman killer on the loose, and Jones plays the man trying to pursue him. The stupidity of the script hit me hard. I rewatched "The Fugitive" not a week after I saw "The Hunted" and realized the sheer genius of it versus the lesser film. This is a movie that will wet the apetite of all action, mystery and thriller lovers alike who are looking for something different than the routine chase films. I know it did for me.4.5/5 stars -John Ulmer

reviews.review_title: Pretty exciting, but overall, a very standard thriller
reviews.content: This is a pretty standard thriller. Harrison Ford performs pretty well, in fact, most of the actors portray their characters very good. I really liked the typical in-your-face smart-ass character that Tommy Lee Jones' played; he was a great comic relief, coupled with Joe Pantoliano. I also enjoyed the inventiveness of Harrison Ford's character, throughout the movie. The plot is interesting, but I guess it's mostly there as an excuse for a mostly standard thriller. The characters are believable and all the actors portray their respective characters well, with no exception. The suspense is pretty good, and it lasts for most of the movie; unfortunately, at the very end it seemed to degenerate into a typical thriller, and for this movie, it just seemed like it had the potential to be better than that. The movie is one of the better thrillers, but it's only worth watching if you like standard thrillers, and you're just looking for the pick of the bunch. I'd only recommend this to fans of standard thrillers, or fans of any of the main actors. 7/10

reviews.review_title: Great action mixed with some incredibly bad acting
reviews.content: I did not know what to think when I saw this movie. I was pulled into the story dealing with Richard Kimball's desperate attempt to find his wife's killer and clear his name. "Wrongly accused" stories always are intriguing. This part of the film was good, you really are pulling for Harrison Ford here. HOWEVER, then you have the supporting cast and story. Here is where it all goes bad. The group of marshals led by Tommy Lee Jones have a script that consists of about three lines. The problem is that they dominate half of the screen time. The result is overacting at its worst. Overplaying skimpy lines and doing it so badly. Dominating camera time and not having anything to do or say. I was shocked at scenes that were included in this film. So much empty filler. There is one marshal with a ponytail, and he is about the worst actor I have ever seen. Am I the only person that saw this? I guess the casting idea was that he was realistic as a marshal, because a real marshal probably would not know how to act either? Is it his fault, or does he just not have a well written role? Not sure, but it is bad. Truth be told, this is a rather simplistic action story. However, by putting Ford and Jones in the leads, you get some credibility. I just wish that they had spent a little more time trying to develop a smarter script and some better acting.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest Cat-and-Mouse suspense movies ever!
reviews.content: I didn't expect much of The Fugitive when I first slipped it into my VCR, but after I saw this movie I almost kicked myself for thinking of such a thing because it was terrific! Tommy Lee Jones won an academy award for his portrayal of a U. S Marshal sent out to find and re-capture Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford, in (you can probobly guess) another smart and likeable role). But Kimble was sentenced guilty for the murder of his wife... but he didn't do it! Now Kimble has the strong U.S marshals chasing him, while Kimble himself is chasing the man he thought did it. Yes, yes, yes of course it sounds routine, but what makes this movie enjoyable are the strong performances,a very smart story  and endless plot twists to wrap it all up. This movie is truely enjoyable. 9.0/10

One of Harrison Ford's most magnificant, significant and most highly acclaimed performances of his career. The Fugitive explores the themes of Justice and Betrayal from a murder case. Harrison Ford plays as Dr. Richard Kimble, a highly respected doctor in Chicago. He has all that he wants; a wife and a succesful promising career. But one night his life turned around. There is someone in his house.........his wife is dead. Now he must run for his life to find the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. With a whole police force behind his back, he will not give up until he finds the man who killed his wife. Co-starring Tommy Lee Jones, this movie is one of the best thrillers out there. It makes us think hard on the themes portrayed in the movie and reminds us that Justice is not always achieved in our world. Harrison Ford's extremely realistic performance as a man on the run, will keep you on the edge of your seat. This film is certainly a classic in the genre.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films of the 90s
reviews.content: There is a thriftiness to the Fugitive which demands appreciation: fifteen minutes in and we're on that prison bus, having been brought up to speed with an introduction that has seen the good doctor Richard Kimble falsely accused of murdering his own wife, and sentenced to death by lethal injection. Seventeen minutes in, after an amazing twist of fate, Richard is free. This is where the story begins; and what follows is a relentless, desperate pursuit, and a masterclass in adrenalized filmmaking.Captivating from its opening scenes, the film draws its characters flawlessly and with intelligence, setting them into a classic Hitchcock-like story of a falsely accused man, and his pursuers who begin to suspect he is innocent. The narrative would be overly complex if it wasn't told so deftly: three simultaneous investigations play out - the search for Richard, Richard's search for his wife's killer, the elusive 'one armed man', and the US Marshals who begin to take Richard's side, and re-open the investigation into his wife's murder. The growing bond between Richard and Marshal Samuel Gerard, who spend most of the film running toward or from one another, is the heart.There is a haunting sense of the inevitable in the Fugitive which is unforgettable, even all these years later; its mournful score has fused itself into my memory, and its wonderful set of actors irremovable from the characters they play. I've seen it countless times; it has the ability to completely remove me from critical thought, and just forces me to sit back and enjoy the ride.This is a technically genius, highly re-watchable film, which has both brains and brawn.

reviews.review_title: A murder is committed, an innocent husband convicted, an escape happens, and the chase for "The Fugitive" is on.
reviews.content: This movie version, based on the television series of the same title, hits on all cylinders that can make a movie great.  There's action aplenty, astonishing escapes by the fugitive, played by Harrison Ford, near-misses by the pursuing US Marshall, played by Tommy Lee Jones, fantastic stunts on screen, and suspense that holds the viewer on the edge of his/her seat. This is a definite film to grace a collection of any home viewer.If one recalls, the TV series had a doctor wrongly convicted of the crime of murdering his wife, when the real killer was an one-armed man.  Dr. Kimble escaped from his prison lock-up, then spent several tv seasons hunting for the guilty killer, and at the same time, trying to avoid being recaptured by a Lt. Gerard.  The movie makes use of the basic program, but then alters the escape of Dr. Kimble, limits the locality to Chicago, and introduces a drug-related scheme that Kimble stumbled onto, and would have prevented a medical company from reaping millions of dollars in the drug's sale.The viewer is asked to follow "The Fugitive" as he stays just one jump, literally, ahead of the law.  There's a very realistic train wreck staged, which helps spring the good doctor, a leap down a waterfall, which keeps him out of the clutches of the US Marshal Gerard, and many more realistic stunts.  Catch this film, on tape, or DVD.  9/10

reviews.review_title: I didn't kill my wife! I don't care.
reviews.content:
The Fugitive is a 1993 thriller directed by Andrew Davis and starring Harrison Ford, Tommy Lee Jones and Sela Ward.
When I first saw that it would be broadcasted on TV I wasn't expecting much of the film, it honestly just seemed like a generic thriller to me but after looking it up I discovered that it was actually very well regarded, with a 7.8/10 on IMDb and a metascore of 87, so I watched it and while at first it did just seem like a forgettable film I quickly became extremely invested in it and by the end it became one of my favorite film of the 90's!!
The movie has a very intriguing and gripping plot and it is very suspenseful for the most part.
The performances are good and I particularly like Tommy Lee Jones and Harrison Ford.
There are a lot of great and suspenseful sequences, my favorite being the iconic part in the dam.
9.2/10
Really good movie. Action suspense, great acting, good storyline. One of Harrison Fords better movies.

One of the greatest thrillers of all time, The Fugitive is a textbook example of a thriller that keeps its audience glued without insulting their intelligence. Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), a Chicago surgeon, is wrongly convicted of killing his wife (Sela Ward), escapes from prison and heads back to his hometown in search of the real killer, a mysterious one-armed man that Kimble struggled with in his house after his wife's murder. U.S. Marshal Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones, in his Oscar-winning role) and his deputies relentlessly pursue Kimble in and around Chicago, always staying a few steps behind. This movie works on so many levels, but it begins with the actors. Harrison Ford, is one of his best roles, perfectly portrays the dignity and righteous indignation that Kimble feels. He should have received an Oscar nomination for the sheer physical and emotional effort that he put into this character. Jones is a perfect choice for Gerard: He is relentless, shrewd and sarcastic in his quest to track down Kimble. He always projects a smarmy, superior quality that attracts the viewer, yet makes us want him to lose his prey. The terrific supporting cast includes Joe Pantoliano, Andreas Katsulas, Daniel Roebuck, and Jeroen Krabbe. Director Andrew Davis takes the audience along for the chase, and uses Chicago as his landscape, including a busy St. Patrick's Day Parade for one scene. These locations enhance the film by using the city as a maze through which this chase occurs. Another terrific feature is James Newton Howard's score, which manages to add color and tension to scenes, even when there is no dialogue. Perfect all around, from acting, directing, composing and screenplay, The Fugitive should remain a classic. Vote: 10

Entertaining, well written, and well acted. This film will have you on the edge of your seat as the plot unfolds. The twists and turns during the second half of the film add plenty of unpredictability that I was simply not expecting. Harrison Ford gives a solid performance here but Tommy Lee Jones is definitely the stand-out. Jones's charisma jumps off the screen in every scene he is in. My one minor negative would be that the film begins to have a bit of a surreal plot after being extremely grounded in reality, so it took me out of the film slightly. However, one gripe didn't stop me from enjoying the heck out of this classic!

The Fugitive pits Harrison Ford against the U.S. Marshall's as he races to find the man who murdered his wife and got him framed for the murder. What ends up happening is Tommy Lee Jones is hired as one of the U.S. Marshall's to hunt down Ford. As the troubled doctor, Ford conveys his emotions perfectly, showing a soft side yet a grim determination to find out what really happened. As the Marshall, Tommy Lee Jones gives off one of his most serious performances that injects a very well- crafted hard edge. Unfortunately, Tommy Lee Jones was awarded an Academy Award for his performance, and it was a definite must that Schindler's List star Ralph F. should have won. The script is kinetic and perfectly structured by providing fierce energy with some very witty and carefully worded dialogue. The direction is unusually emotional as it dwells quite a bit upon Ford's trauma on the death of his wife. Things connect well enough but there are some flaws too. Some of the chase sequences (Ford jumping into the water) were just downright insane and stood out as being totally unrealistic. Also, the pace was too slow sometimes as it got repeating from chase to chase to chase. A similar problem was encountered in Steven Spielberg's Catch Me if You Can. The Fugitive stands out as one of the few sharp modern thrillers and is a definite must for fans of the genre. 9/10

reviews.review_title: An all-time chase thriller with 2 enduring performances
reviews.content: THE FUGITIVE is one of the very few examples where a film adaptation of a hit TV show perhaps surpasses that TV show in scope, ambition, and payoff. The classic 1960s series "THE FUGITIVE", starring the perfectly cast David Janssen as somber, falsely accused Dr. Richard Kimble, has been one-upped by this 1993 masterpiece of an action-adventure film THE FUGITIVE, starring the rugged, unique Harrison Ford in the role of Kimble. Ford has similarities to Janssen, but there are also differences. Ford is much more burly and more of an intimidating presence than Janseen was and so you couldn't see Janssen kicking someone's ass the way Ford could. But Ford definitely does excellent job of capturing the calm, meek, quiet nature that Janssen so perfectly conveyed in the series, with added touches of desperation and fear. This is important as Kimble was always designed to be a 'regular everyday Joe', one of us. We HAVE to relate to him and sympathize with him and the more cocky, brutish characters that Ford has played in the past (Han Solo, Indiana Jones, etc.) have no part in this movie. I just hate that Ford didn't get a Best Actor nomination for this film as it is truly a performance deserving of one.The 2nd great performance in this already-classic film is that of Tommy Lee Jones, who truly came into his own with this movie. He won Oscar for Best Supporting Actor, but c'mon! We all know he was really the 2nd lead of this film. Jones plays Kimble's pursuer Deputy Marshal Sam Gerard (in the series it was Barry Morse playing Lt. Philip Gerard). About the only thing Jones and Morse have in common is that they are short men. That's about it! While Morse was much more calm and reserved as Gerard, Jones' Gerard is all out full-throttle, in-your-face, get-the-job-done-or-else version of the character. Full of juice throughout the entire film, Jones conveys a man obsessed with doing his job at whatever cost, but along the way, we get to see flashes of humanity and insight that makes us realize that Gerard isn't just some carbon copy blind cop. He begins to realize that maybe Kimble's assertion that he didn't kill his wife might be true. Kimble is a 'fugitive' and Gerard is fully within his right to arrest him and bring him in, whether Kimble is guilty of his convicted crime or not, but at the same time, Gerard's no-nonsense persona shines at welcome moments when he's dealing with people who are either buffoonish, deceptive, or apathetic. This is a key ingredient that makes this film work.Another brilliant aspect of this film is all the minor characters that Kimble encounters along the way, none of which have a big role, but all seem like actual people, just going about their everyday business. But none of these characters detract from the main plot of the film, thus THE FUGITIVE flows throughout.Like many great action films, the film contains some exciting scenes and set pieces (the train crash, the dam chase, the county jail chase, and the exciting climax with the one-armed man).Special mention should also go to the actors (Daniel Roebuck, L. Scott Caldwell, Tom Wood, and especially Joe Pantoliano), who play Gerard's deputies aiding him in the search for Kimble. The chemistry of this group is totally convincing and fun to watch and listen to.Andrew Davis directed this Best Picture nominee from 1993 and I would definitely rate it as one of the best films of the 1990s and one of the best action films ever!

The Fugitive (1993) *** 1/2 (out of 4) After wrongfully being convicted of murdering his wife, Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford) gets a chance to escape and try and track down the real killer but he's got a U.S. Marshall (Tommy Lee Jones) in hot pursuit. Based on the popular 60's TV show, THE FUGITIVE works on so many levels that it's easy to see why it became a hit when originally released and why it remains so popular nearly twenty-years later. I think the greatest thing that the film has going for it is that it basically works as two very good films rolled into one. The first forty-five minutes or so we're given a terrific action film that starts off with an introduction to the murder and conviction of the doctor and then we go full steam into the intense action. We get a terrific train-bus wreck, which is still impressive all these years later and right from here we go for faster action as we see Kimble trying to evade the police and the U.S. Marshall. These scenes are full of wonderful action but the way Andrew Davis keeps the suspense building is where the true magic is. The second half of the film sees a little less action as we find the doctor doing the investigating trying to figure out who killed his wife. Both sequences work so well and especially when you mix them together as you really get a complete film. It also doesn't hurt that you've got two great performances. Ford could play this type of role in his sleep but I still don't think he got enough credit. He's really not playing an action hero here, I mean, serious, he gets beaten by a one-armed man. He really plays a doctor here who must go beyond his normal limits to try and clear his name and I thought Ford did a great job with it. There's no question, however, that the film belongs to Jones who rightfully picked up the Best Supporting Oscar for his work here. I really loved the comic timing that Jones brought the film and I thought this humor really helped make the film so memorable. The highlight for me has to be the scene where a woman is screaming uncontrollably and Jones simply tells her to shut up. Joe Pantoliano, Sela Ward and a briefly scene Julianne Moore are also good in their parts. THE FUGITIVE ends in a way you'd expect it to but there's still no question that it's a tense little thriller that works on most levels.

When this movie came out in 1993, I was curious about several things. (1) How Harrison Ford would play the role as opposed to David Janssen. Ford did a great job of playing a specialist in a big city hospital. I thought, though, that since David Janssen's Dr. Kimble was a pediatrician in a small town, his was a more likable character. Also, Harrison Ford's Dr. Kimble had a pretty weak motive. Why would a vascular surgeon want to murder his wife for money? David Janssen's Dr. Kimble at least had a bone of contention with his wife, although I know we can't blame Harrison Ford for that.(2) How would they handle Dr. Kimble roaming from town to town solving everyone's problems and moving on in the neighborhood of two hours? (3) How long could Dr. Kimble run and hide, considering forensics were much better in the mid 90s than they were in the mid 60s? I admit I went into that movie ready to compare it to the original TV series, and was ready to rip it to shreds. However, the more I got involved in the movie, the more I forgot that it was spawned from my all-time favorite television show. This movie is pretty doggone exciting. By the time I got out of the theater, I had made up my mind that The Fugitive was a great movie and a great TV show. 9 out of 10 for this one.

I remember there being a lot of hype around this movie when i was younger, i only just saw it recently and now i know why. This is a great movie, very engaging and re-watchable.
Harrison Ford in his leading man prime plays a doctor who is framed for his wife's murder and goes on the run to prove his innocence while being pursued by a relentless U.S marshall played by Tommy Lee Jones.
It's just over 2 hours long but it doesn't feel like a long movie because not a single scene is wasted, there's always something happening and the plot moves forward at a break neck pace. The characters feel like real people in the way they act and speak and nothing is over exaggerated which is something i love about these kinds of movies. There's some really great stunt work especially during the famous dam scene and the train crash where i'm not sure if it was an optical effect or a stunt man risking his life for the shot.
Very enjoyable movie with a great cast and a well written story. That's all you need to make a great movie sometimes.

reviews.review_title: Hey, Tommy! I Love Those Little Sprinkles, Too!
reviews.content: One of the better action movies of the 1990s, Andrew Davis' The Fugitive retells the long-lived television series' story of a man, hunted by the police, trying to prove his innocence in the murder of his wife.The story itself has such a long life-span. I think the TV show was based on the Sam Shepard murder case. The Fugitive ran for four years and ABC had the class and daring to conclude the series at the end of August in 1967. It was a tremendous ratings hit, even with most of the country sweltering under a late August heat.Even though I was a little kid, I liked watching The Fugitive reruns on daytime TV--the concept of poor David Janssen one step in front of the heat, and meeting new and interesting people whom he didn't dare get too close to was appealing even to a 9 year old. I watched the finale, with Janssen grappling on a water tower or something, with the one-armed killer, an unnervingly ordinary-looking shlub.When I heard Harrison Ford was going to be in a remake of the story, I naturally was interested. Ford is a one-act wonder, but he is a sympathetic character and I wanted to see what Hollywood had to say about Dr. Richard Kimble's adventures a quarter century after the end of the series.What we got was a tightly-plotted, almost always believable adventure with Ford in . . . a minor role.It's really Tommy Lee Jones' hammy, eccentric, and startlingly cold-blooded performance as US Marshall Gerard-- Kimble: "I didn't kill my wife!" Gerard: "I DON'T CARE!" --that makes the movie work. And it saves Ford from being so bland and ordinary that the viewer would dismiss him early on. We know he didn't kill his wife. We need a foil, a not-really-a-villain who will keep hounding Ford's Kimble, keep scaring him and us with, well, Jones' face and his dogged determination.Jones is the sharp, bitter thread of chocolate in Ford's vanilla. And damned if it doesn't work.With the crispness of Davis' direction, the locked-in likability factor for Ford and Jones, some really great stunts (except for the ludicrous jump from a dam sluice way), and location shooting in Chicago and North Carolina (doubling up somehow for Illinois), The Fugitive is a taught, crafty chase film that only runs into trouble when the reason for the murder of Kimble's wife is revealed, a stale, chestnutty back-story.Kimble's wife is played by the lovely Sela Ward and we, unfortunately, only get to see her a few times where she isn't getting murdered or lying there, a bloody corpse. I suspect that, if there was more footage of her, it wound up in the editor's wastebasket.Well, enough bloviating. The Fugitive is a fine piece of genre work. It's scary and fun, but not silly.Silliness is a movie sin I have found less and less forgivable over the years.

reviews.review_title: I have forgotten what a good movie it was
reviews.content: Ahh, the old times.Nice to see a clever movie with plot twist and old school punches.

reviews.review_title: Not just great then but also great today - 89%
reviews.content: You know how you have that "Must See" list of films that you never get round to watching? I had "The Long Kiss Goodnight" on my list for 10 years but this movie trumps that, a long 16 years after release! Question is, was it worth the wait? Well, yes and no. Obviously, no film is worth waiting that long for unless you're the sort of obsessive fan associated with certain sci-fi franchises.
